Module chav1961.purelib
Package chav1961.purelib.json

Class JsonUtils

java.lang.Object
chav1961.purelib.json.JsonUtils
public class JsonUtils
extends java.lang.Object

This class contains a set of static methods to work with JsonNode tree. All the methods can be grouped as:

  • loadJsonTree(JsonStaxParser) and unloadJsonTree(JsonNode, JsonStaxPrinter) methods to load/unload JSON content into or from JsonNode tree
  • walkDownJson(JsonNode, JsonTreeWalkerCallback) method to walk JSON tree from it's root or any subtree

This class also contains a builder to create XPath-styled filter for use in conjunction with walkDownJson(JsonNode, JsonTreeWalkerCallback) method to simplify JSON tree walking. Syntax of the filter see filterOf(String, JsonTreeWalkerCallback) method description

Since:
0.0.4
Author:
Alexander Chernomyrdin aka chav1961

  • Method Details

    • loadJsonTree

      public static JsonNode loadJsonTree​(JsonStaxParser parser) throws SyntaxException, java.lang.NullPointerException

      Build JSON node tree from JSON parser

      Parameters:
      parser - parser to build node. Parser must be pointed to any JSON lexema into it. Call parser.next() method before pass it to the method, if you doesn't call it earlier
      Returns:
      root of the JSON node tree. Can't be null
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - parser is null
      SyntaxException - any syntax errors in the input stream

    • unloadJsonTree

      public static void unloadJsonTree​(JsonNode root, JsonStaxPrinter printer) throws PrintingException, java.lang.NullPointerException

      Unload JSON tree into JSON printer.

      Parameters:
      root - root of JSON tree
      printer - printer to print JSON tree content
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - root or printer is null
      PrintingException - any exceptions on printing

    • walkDownJson

      public static ContinueMode walkDownJson​(JsonNode root, JsonTreeWalkerCallback callback) throws ContentException, java.lang.NullPointerException

      Walk down the JSON tree

      Parameters:
      root - root of JSON tree
      callback - callback to process nodes
      Returns:
      last ContinueMode code from the walker
      Throws:
      java.lang.NullPointerException - root or printer is null
      ContentException - on any processing errors in the callback

    • filterOf

      public static JsonTreeWalkerCallback filterOf​(java.lang.String expression, JsonTreeWalkerCallback nested) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException, java.lang.NullPointerException, SyntaxException

      Build callback filter for JSON tree. It's functionality is similar to XPath in the XML DOM tree

      Syntax of the 'XPath' expression in BNF is typed below. Character sequences inside apostrophes are treated as-is (for example, ':' is treated as colon typed):

      • '/'<nodeSelector> - reference to the root node
      • './'<nodeSelector> - reference to the current node
      • '../'<nodeSelector> - reference to the parent node

      <nodeSelector> consists of <nodeTemplate>[':'<valueTemplate>]['#'<filter>]

      Current and parent node references in the 'XPath' can be used multiple time, but only in the beginning of the 'XPath'. Node template can be:

      • / - any node
      • /* - any object node
      • /[] - any array node
      • /** - any node chain
      • /<name> - any object node with the given name. Name can contain wildcards '*' and '?'
      • /[<indexExpr>] - any array node with the given index selected. Index can contains index expression (see below)

      Value template can be:

      • <valueTemplate>::=<rangeItem>','... - list of ranges
      • <rangeItem>::=<value>['..']<value> - range of values (similar to BETWEEN / AND in the SQL language)
      • <value>::={<int>|<real>|<boolean>|<null>|<string>} - value in the JSON-styled notation

      Syntax of the index expression is:

      • <indexExpr>::={<list>|'has' <condition>}
      • <list>::=<range>[','<range>...]
      • <range>::=<expr>['..'<expr>]
      • <condition>::=<andCondition>['||'<andCondition>...]
      • <andCondition>::=<notCondition>['&&'<notCondition>...]
      • <notCondition>::=[~]<comparison>
      • <comparison>::={<expr>{'>'|'>='|'<'|'<='|'=='|'<>'}<expr>|<expr>'in'<list>|<expr>'is'{'int'|'real'|'str'|'bool'|'null'|'arr'|'obj'}}
      • <expr>::=<term>{'+'|'-'|'*'|'/'|'%'}<term>...
      • <term>::={'i'|<value>|'('<expr>')'}

      Variable 'i' always is treated as index of the current element and can be used in the condition index expressions only. Priority of the logical and arithmetical operators in the expression is traditional.

      Syntax of the 'filter' expression is:

      • <filter>::=<expr>{'&&'|'||'}<expr>...
      • <expr>::=[~]<term>
      • <term>::={<xpath> [<comparison>] |'('<filter>')'}

      XPath in the filter without any comparison operators treated as 'check existance', otherwise compared with the given right part of comparison operator. Right part of '=' and '<>' comparisons for the 'XPath' can contain JSON in the form of '<JSON_content>', for example "../ = '{"name":"var1","value":[10,20]}'".

      Examples of the syntax are:

      • / ** / [0..2] - all node arrays with indices 0, 1, and 2
      • / ** / [0..2] / ** - all children of the node arrays with indices 0, 1, and 2
      • / ** / [has(i%2 == 0)] - all node arrays with even indices
      • / ** / name #../key:10 && ../type:"type1" - all node with 'name' name in the structure with 'key' field = 10 and 'type' field = "type1"
      • / ** / name #../ = '{"name":"test","type":"20"}' - all node with 'name', where parent of node is exactly equals for JSON '{"name":"test","type":"20"}'

      Filter built is not reentrant and doesn't be used recursively, but it is reusable and doesn't need re-creation for subsequential calls

      Parameters:
      expression - expression to filter content
      nested - nested callback will be called on all the nodes successfully filtered by the filter expressions
      Returns:
      filter callback. Can't be null. Pass it to walkDownJson(JsonNode, JsonTreeWalkerCallback) method directly
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - expression is null or empty
      java.lang.NullPointerException - nested callback is null
      SyntaxException - any syntax errors in the expression
      See Also:
      walkDownJson(JsonNode, JsonTreeWalkerCallback)
